headline.main: The Future of the Obama Coalition

docs.abstract: If the Democrats concede a majority of the white working class vote, what have they got left?
docs.snippet: If the Democrats concede a majority of the white working class vote, what have they got left?

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, Democrats have suffered continuous and increasingly severe losses among white voters. But preparations by Democratic operatives for the 2012 election make it clear for the first time that the party will explicitly abandon the white working class.

headline.main: The Future of the Obama Coalition

docs.lead_paragraph: It’s easy to attribute our failures of will to our biology. But it’s wrong.
docs.abstract: Psychology Profs Greg Walton and Carol Dweck Gray Matter column asserts that their research on willpower has shown that those who believe that willpower is powerful tend to exert it to a much greater degree for a longer period of time; notes that those who did not believe in willpower tended to give up more readily on activities.
docs.snippet: It’s easy to attribute our failures of will to our biology. But it’s wrong.

byline.original: By GREG WALTON and CAROL DWECK

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of people are starving unnecessarily in Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia. The world knows how to prevent drought-induced famine. So why doesn’t it?
docs.abstract: Health reporter Samuel Loewenberg Op-Ed article, prompted by failure of international response to help drought-induced famine in Somalia and other countries in Africa, concedes that while droughts cannot be stopped, the economics that link drought and famine can be upended; cites common misconception that hunger crises are about a lack of food, but holds they are really the result of such dire poverty among people who have so little that when things turn bad, they have no recourse.
docs.snippet: Millions of people are starving unnecessarily in Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia. The world knows how to prevent drought-induced famine. So why doesn’t it?

headline.main: Get Stuffed | A Cup o' Pumpkin Pie

docs.abstract: Before you devour your second (third?) slice of Mom's leftover homemade pumpkin pie, opt for a still seasonal but healthy alternative: an organic, sugar-free pumpkin pie smoothie.
docs.snippet: Before you devour your second (third?) slice of Mom's leftover homemade pumpkin pie, opt for a still seasonal but healthy alternative: an organic, sugar-free pumpkin pie smoothie.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before you devour your second (third?) slice of Mom's leftover homemade pumpkin pie, opt for a still seasonal but healthy alternative: an organic, sugar-free pumpkin pie smoothie. Created by Dr. Frank Lipman, the founder and director of the Eleven Eleven Wellness Center in Manhattan -- which promotes "good medicine," like lifestyle changes through diet, nutrition, exercise and stress management -- this dessert complies with his challenging but not impossible 14-day-long "Be Well" food-and-shake cleanse ($200). The gluten-free treat substitutes unsweetened vanilla almond milk for cream and calls for organic pumpkin and a little raw honey or cinnamon in place of sugar. "When you eat sugars, your body gets an initial surge of energy, your body scrambles to process it, and then you crash," Lipman says about sugar, a depression-linked carbohydrate. "This process triggers the body to crave more sugar, and a vicious cycle of craving, eating and crashing begins." Sounds alarmingly familiar, eh? On the bright side, Lipman does promote a lot of sleep to combat sugar cravings around the holidays. The easy-to-follow recipe is below, so you can nap and have all the taste of pumpkin pie you want this holiday season.Pumpkin Pie Smoothie - Serves 1
